content: As cities grow, an increased population has both positive and negative effects on quality of life. The most important effects are reviewed below.

sections.name: The Economic Rationale of Cities
content: The primary purpose of a city is to facilitate the exchange of goods, services, and information [glaeser92]. A city is typically defined as an urban area through which people can commute on a daily basis. Larger cities tend to create more wealth by offering wider job markets, labor pools, and diversity of products for sale.
Dense cities, and the amenities they support, foster collaboration [patent_move][microgeography], with results in, for instance, more patents [cities_patents].

Due to this agglomeration effect, there is a tendency for population growth to concentrate in existing cities rather than new cities. There should be other factors to motivate the construction of new cities, particularly in an exotic location that is far from existing cities.

sections.name: Cities and Transportation
content: Cities fit into the larger national and world economies, and consequently they need to exchange goods, services, information, and people beyond their borders to thrive. There is extensive evidence (for example, [beyz]) that access to intercity transportation is a major factor in city success.

Better transportation, together with telecommunications, have been found to help foster academic collaboration [clancy_academia] and joint patenting [clancy_patent]. The advancement of telecommunications in particular has been important [clancy_spillovers].

sections.name: Drawbacks of Big Cities
content: To reap the environmental and economic benefits that come with density, it is necessary to mitigate the drawbacks. Larger and denser cities tend to have higher traffic congestion [traffic164], crime [hanley], and infectious disease [city_size_disease]. Light pollution, noise pollution, and the urban heat island effect are challenges that grow with density; see our analyses of these topics and proposals to mitigate them.
